title: India's capital to observe first car-free day on 22 October
text:
India's capital to observe first car-free day on 22 October 14 October 2015 
The Delhi Government is set to observe a car-free day in India's capital city on 22 October, as part of its efforts to ease traffic congestion and reduce air pollution. 
Proposed by the ruling Aam Admi Party (AAP), the Ab Bus Karein campaign was initially met resistance from the city police, which denied permission and urged the government to change the date as it coincided with Dussehra and Durga Puja immersions. 
However, the department has been directed by Delhi governor lieutenant Najeeb Jung to make special arrangements for the event, which is scheduled to be observed from 7am local time to 12 noon. 
The car-free zone will be declared on the stretch from the Red Fort to India Gate running through ITO - the Netaji Subhas Marg, Bahadur Shah Zafar Marg, and Tilak Marg, reported IANS. 
While the initiative restricts private vehicles, commuters can ride bicycles, or use taxis and auto-rickshaws through a mobile application called Puchho. 
In addition, Delhi transport minister Gopal Rai told The Times of India that the government will operate 20 DTC buses as shuttle services between India Gate and Red Fort for commuters. 
Local environmentalists have expressed concerns that a single car-free day will not stop trucks and diesel-vehicles or clean the air in the capital. "Without any restraint on the movement of trucks, Delhi's battle against toxic pollution cannot be won." 
According to a Centre for Science and Environment (CSE) study, Delhi has 7.35 million vehicles and 1,400 new vehicles are added on a daily basis, in addition to nearly 39,000 diesel run commercial vehicles that enter the city every day from nine locations, which increases the high pollution levels. 
CSE director general Sunita Narain said: "This is clearly a massive loading of toxic pollution. 
"Without any restraint on the movement of these trucks, Delhi's battle against toxic pollution cannot be won." 
The neighbouring Gurgaon Government has been observing the car-free event for the past three weeks on four of the busiest stretches from 7am to 7pm, Hindustan Times reported.
